qas.question: Insects play prominent roles in what?
What is a common insect used for research purposes?
Drosophila has helped develop principles in what kind of linkage?
Genetic systems are conserved among what?
What percent of the fly genome is similar to the human genome

context: Insects play important roles in <a0_0>biological research<a0_0/>. For example, because of its small size, short generation time and high fecundity, the common <a1_0>fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster<a1_0/> is a model organism for studies in the genetics of higher eukaryotes. D. melanogaster has been an essential part of studies into principles like <a2_0>genetic<a2_0/> linkage, interactions between genes, chromosomal genetics, development, behavior and evolution. Because genetic systems are well conserved among <a3_0>eukaryotes<a3_0/>, understanding basic cellular processes like DNA replication or transcription in fruit flies can help to understand those processes in other eukaryotes, including humans. The genome of D. melanogaster was sequenced in 2000, reflecting the organism's important role in biological research. It was found that <a4_0>70%<a4_0/> of the fly genome is similar to the human genome, supporting the evolution theory.
